Interoceptive Sensations of Motherhood (iSoM) Section 1 Introduction

Interoceptive Sensations of Motherhood (iSoM) Paul W. Savoca & Bridget L. Callaghan 2024-01-04 Section 1 Introduction This wiki contains information for the Interoceptive Sensations of Motherhood (iSoM) Study.

Section 2 Overview 2.1 Summary Interoceptive Sensations of Motherhood (iSoM) Wiki 2.2 Aims 2.3 Background iSoM is the in-person follow-up study to Sensations of Motherhood (SoM). Currently, the primary aim of the study is to collect pilot data for a grant application.
Section 3 Pilot Study 3.1 Pilot Overview 3.2 Pilot Details 3.3 Questionnaires 3.4 Funding

Section 3 Pilot Study 3.1 Pilot Overview Overview of Piloting Aims/Goals - To demonstrate the feasiblity of collecting in-person measures of interoception in pregnant women. - Collect pilot data for grant. 3.2 Pilot Details Questionnaires Open the REDCap Questionnaires on the iPad Hand the participant the iPad and ask them to complete the questionnaires You can let them know: Each questionnaire will automatically proceed to the next If they have any questions, they can ask you for clarification It should take approximately 15 minutes When the participant has completed the questionnaires, they will return the iPad to you. Physiological Hook-up Ask the participant if they need to use the rest room Collect Height and Weight measurements (enter into REDCap). Ask the participant if they have any skin allergies or sensitives Summarize/explain the physiology procedure to the participant i.e., “Ok, so now I am going to place some sensors on your body. The sensors will stick to your skin but can be easily peeled off. I will place two sensors on your right and left collarbones, and one on your lower left rib cage. I will clean the area with an alcohol wipe and some gauze. I will walk you through everything as we go, but if you have any questions or anything feels uncomfortable, don’t hesitate to let me know.” Place ECG Electrodes: Find where you will place sensor Clean the area with the alcohol wipe and then gauze Apply a small dot of electrode gel to the sensor Stick the sensor to the skin Repeat for all 3 spots Have Participant sit in chair (in front of stimulus computer). Attached leads to electrodes ECG & Respiration attach to same transmitter Check Signals in Acqknowledge HBD Task Open Psychopy Run HBD Task First complete 2-min baseline Then explain task instructions Have participant complete task (40 trials) Clean-up Stop the physio recording Detect the wires from the participant Have participant remove sensors They can do this themselves or you can help if they prefer “Ripping it off like a Band-Aid” is NOT best approach typically Hold the skin, while peeling up, usually works best – if sensors are particularly sticky Pilot Interview After completing the HBD task and removing sensors, complete the pilot interview Verbally ask questions to the participant and take notes of their answers in REDCap 3.3 Questionnaires Demographics BAB Lab Health Questionnaire Childhood Trauma Questionnaire Pennebaker, J. W., & Susman, J. R. (1988). Disclosure of traumas and psychosomatic processes. Social science & medicine, 26(3), 327-332. Edinburgh Postnatal Depression Scale Cox, J. L., Holden, J. M., & Sagovsky, R. (1987). Detection of postnatal depression: development of the 10-item Edinburgh Postnatal Depression Scale.The British journal of psychiatry,150(6), 782-786. Interoceptive Accuracy Scale (IAS) Murphy, J., Brewer, R., Plans, D., Khalsa, S. S., Catmur, C., & Bird, G. (2020). Testing the independence of self-reported interoceptive accuracy and attention. Quarterly Journal of Experimental Psychology, 73(1), 115-133. Multidimensional Assessment of Interoceptive Awareness 2 (MAIA-2) Mehling WE, Acree M, Stewart A, Silas J, Jones A (2018) The Multidimensional Assessment of Interoceptive Awareness, Version 2 (MAIA-2). PLoS ONE 13(12): e0208034. 3.4 Funding Start-up Funds
Section 4 Data Collection 4.1 Location 4.2 HBD Task 4.3 Data Storage

Section 4 Data Collection 4.1 Location All research is conducted in-person at UCLA. 4.2 HBD Task The HBD task is programed using Psychopy. The HBD device is built using an Ardunio Uno3. The Task contains 40 trials (10 beats per trial). For each trial, participants responds for accuracy (Output: 1 = in-sync; 0 = out-of-sync), and confidence (0-100 continuous; Greater value = more confident.) “In-sync” trials have a fixed offset of 200ms. “Out-of-sync” trials have a fixed offset of 500ms. 4.3 Data Storage The questionnaire data is stored in REDCap. Physiological data and HBD Task outputs are stored on Box.
